post.title: When you discuss your religious beliefs on Reddit

body:
Yeah this is how I see the world. If God is behind the concept of existence itself then the proof is the existence itself. Physics and chemistry are the code he used. That's the proof. 

It's like fish in a tank in an empty room. Imagine they were smart enough to study the composition of the glass and the ph of the water. A fish says "look! This glass is amazing and is beyond our ability to create. Look! This ph is set just right for us. There must be a creator."

And the neckbeard fish says "heh. Okay fundie. What's your proof? You think a different, hyper intelligent creature who exists beyond this tank made the glass? Lol okay idiot. I bet you believe in fairies too". 

What proof could there even be? Do they expect to see "lol God was here" written inside an atom?

post.title: When you discuss your religious beliefs on Reddit

body:
The original tenant of agnosticism was the belief that due to how limited human intelligence is, we have to accept there are answers to questions we will never ever have answered.

Is there a god? Is there a creator? Did everything start off with an explosion of just because? Does the universe have a type of will?

My answer is that its impossible for the human race to ever find out how the universe started, or if someone created it. And we have to accept that.

That’s it.

Anyone that claims they know how the universe started or who created it, is full of shit. End of story.

I asked my friend who has religious friends, how do people delude themselves into believing in a god?

He says they aren’t delusional, its called a leap of faith for a reason, you just have to trust.

And that one explanation made me understand religion much better than any religious person actually trying to explain god to me.

Faith is simply faith.
body_html:
The original tenant of agnosticism was the belief that due to how limited human intelligence is, we have to accept there are answers to questions we will never ever have answered.

Is there a god? Is there a creator? Did everything start off with an explosion of just because? Does the universe have a type of will?

My answer is that its impossible for the human race to ever find out how the universe started, or if someone created it. And we have to accept that.

That’s it.

Anyone that claims they know how the universe started or who created it, is full of shit. End of story.

I asked my friend who has religious friends, how do people delude themselves into believing in a god?

He says they aren’t delusional, its called a leap of faith for a reason, you just have to trust.

And that one explanation made me understand religion much better than any religious person actually trying to explain god to me.

Faith is simply faith.

author.bio: See you on the other side

body: Fair point, but the kind of proof you're talking about is harder for people nowadays. We've been taught constantly that the universe is a self-sustaining closed system, so it's a lot easier to look at the universe and be amazed by it like you describe, but substitute some natural process or system for God. Something like Aquinas' argument that the universe is a dependent system could be helpful in those cases though.
body_html: Fair point, but the kind of proof you're talking about is harder for people nowadays. We've been taught constantly that the universe is a self-sustaining closed system, so it's a lot easier to look at the universe and be amazed by it like you describe, but substitute some natural process or system for God. Something like Aquinas' argument that the universe is a dependent system could be helpful in those cases though.

It's like fish in a tank in an empty room. Imagine they were smart enough to study the composition of the glass and the ph of the water. A fish says "look! This glass is amazing and is beyond our ability to create. Look! This ph is set just right for us. There must be a creator."

And the neckbeard fish says "heh. Okay fundie. What's your proof? You think a different, hyper intelligent creature who exists beyond this tank made the glass? Lol okay idiot. I bet you believe in fairies too". 

What proof could there even be? Do they expect to see "lol God was here" written inside an atom?

body:
I mean, specifically under those conditions, the premise is flawed.

Yeah we can see time as an abstract concept, but due to human’s low intelligence, the way we perceive time is still the only way we can perceive life, and I trust that every human is following the same framework as I am 

So based on our very limited framework of life that we can all understand, we must accept there are questions to life that we cannot answer.

Questions such as, how did “time” as we know it begin? How did “space” as we know it begin? So on and so forth

post.title: When you discuss your religious beliefs on Reddit

body:
Which is fine.  I'm all in when it comes to science. And if you want to believe in a god, while maintaining that what we know about physics is still true.... okay.  The god of the gaps has currently retreated to before or within 1x10^-13s after the big bang.  If believing in some higher power helps you through your day, and it doesn't interfere with you accepting facts of the world, go for it. 

But it means that you've got to let go of a young-earth, creationism, the literal 6 day creation story, Eve springing forth from a non-metaphorical rib, and Man coming from dust.   You've got to be ok with tectonic plate movement, the solar system coming from an accretion disk,  humans evolving from primates and from mammals, the big bang. And it'd be good to accept modern medicine like blood transfusions.

If believing in some higher power helps you through your day, and it doesn't interfere with you accepting facts of the world, go for it.

But it means that you've got to let go of a young-earth, creationism, the literal 6 day creation story, Eve springing forth from a non-metaphorical rib, and Man coming from dust. You've got to be ok with tectonic plate movement, the solar system coming from an accretion disk, humans evolving from primates and from mammals, the big bang. And it'd be good to accept modern medicine like blood transfusions.

post.title: When you discuss your religious beliefs on Reddit

body:
God can't be fully understood in the thinking mind. It takes a lot of spiritual practice to get a glimpse of what it entails. Eastern philosophy and spiritual practice I feel like is an attractive and good way to open your mind to this.

Science currently is only concerned with the material aspect of conciousness. The scientific method still always operates from a paradigm (which is guaranteed to change with time) and current paradigm lacks the room and tools to measure God. To use current scientific reasoning to interpret God, is missing the point. You're looking trough the wrong glasses.

parent.body:
The original tenant of agnosticism was the belief that due to how limited human intelligence is, we have to accept there are answers to questions we will never ever have answered.

Is there a god? Is there a creator? Did everything start off with an explosion of just because? Does the universe have a type of will?

My answer is that its impossible for the human race to ever find out how the universe started, or if someone created it. And we have to accept that.

That’s it.

Anyone that claims they know how the universe started or who created it, is full of shit. End of story.

I asked my friend who has religious friends, how do people delude themselves into believing in a god?

He says they aren’t delusional, its called a leap of faith for a reason, you just have to trust.

And that one explanation made me understand religion much better than any religious person actually trying to explain god to me.

Faith is simply faith.
parent.body_html:
The original tenant of agnosticism was the belief that due to how limited human intelligence is, we have to accept there are answers to questions we will never ever have answered.

Is there a god? Is there a creator? Did everything start off with an explosion of just because? Does the universe have a type of will?

My answer is that its impossible for the human race to ever find out how the universe started, or if someone created it. And we have to accept that.

That’s it.

Anyone that claims they know how the universe started or who created it, is full of shit. End of story.

I asked my friend who has religious friends, how do people delude themselves into believing in a god?

He says they aren’t delusional, its called a leap of faith for a reason, you just have to trust.

And that one explanation made me understand religion much better than any religious person actually trying to explain god to me.

Faith is simply faith.

body:
Forgive me if this comes across as an attack, but it is a tad arrogant to presume we've achieved mastery over the Universe and the rules which it abides by. If we knew all there is to know, then there'd be nothing left for us to uncover, understand and use to our greatest advantage. Every day new advancements in one field or another are made, so we most certainly have not plateaued. Who'd of thought that you could grow a pigment or dye on aluminum foil for example? What I am saying is; the rulebook we abide by, the lens through which we gaze upon this world, changes with each & every discovery made, so we still have a long way to go before we can declare ourselves all knowing and masters of the universe. 

When speaking of Higher Beings like El Elohim, it's only natural to presume He would undoubtedly of a far higher caliber and know the entire rulebook like the back of His hand well in advance. Rules that we have not yet quite grasped ahold of as not every question that torments mankind has been answered. Not even the most brilliant of minds have been able to answer the eternal question of man: is there life after death? One major point of science is to answer our greatest questions or to solve our dilemmas, but there are still many questions we have that after all this time remain unanswered. It seems every day with one discovery, another question must be asked, so to put it simply; we do not know all the rules. Not at all. That much is certainly clear.

Also being faithful there is a quote I cannot seem to find anymore that often resonates with me:

To try and perceive the ways of God is like your toast trying to better understand you. 

It's silly, but it often quells my hubris.

author.bio: Unironic Anarcho-Monarchist. I also collect stamps.

body:
Yes, God is not only *a* being, but rather the Ground of Being. To borrow a thought from Paul Tillich, it is wrong to state that God exists if by "exists" we mean "exists in the same way as the world". 

I actually think that it is Intelligent Design (ID) who muddies the waters here. ID claims to be a scientific proof of God. But if ID can prove anything, it can merely prove that *something* created the world without specifying what that *something* is (God? Angels? Aliens? A supercomputer from the future? etc.). So when atheists encounter ID argumentation, they can get the impression that ontologically speaking, God is indistinguishable from all other beings. 

This is why Thomas Aquinas' proofs of God are better, because they are logically more coherent. For example, his cosmological argument works even if it should turn out that the universe is eternal and not created *ex nihilo*. What Aquinas and Anselm and friends prove (or tries to prove) is not merely that *something* created the world, but that that *something* have to be God.

I actually think that it is Intelligent Design (ID) who muddies the waters here. ID claims to be a scientific proof of God. But if ID can prove anything, it can merely prove that something created the world without specifying what that something is (God? Angels? Aliens? A supercomputer from the future? etc.). So when atheists encounter ID argumentation, they can get the impression that ontologically speaking, God is indistinguishable from all other beings.

This is why Thomas Aquinas' proofs of God are better, because they are logically more coherent. For example, his cosmological argument works even if it should turn out that the universe is eternal and not created ex nihilo. What Aquinas and Anselm and friends prove (or tries to prove) is not merely that something created the world, but that that something have to be God.

Yeah this is how I see the world. If God is behind the concept of existence itself then the proof is the existence itself. Physics and chemistry are the code he used. That's the proof. 

It's like fish in a tank in an empty room. Imagine they were smart enough to study the composition of the glass and the ph of the water. A fish says "look! This glass is amazing and is beyond our ability to create. Look! This ph is set just right for us. There must be a creator."

And the neckbeard fish says "heh. Okay fundie. What's your proof? You think a different, hyper intelligent creature who exists beyond this tank made the glass? Lol okay idiot. I bet you believe in fairies too". 

What proof could there even be? Do they expect to see "lol God was here" written inside an atom?

parent.body:
The original tenant of agnosticism was the belief that due to how limited human intelligence is, we have to accept there are answers to questions we will never ever have answered.

Is there a god? Is there a creator? Did everything start off with an explosion of just because? Does the universe have a type of will?

My answer is that its impossible for the human race to ever find out how the universe started, or if someone created it. And we have to accept that.

That’s it.

Anyone that claims they know how the universe started or who created it, is full of shit. End of story.

I asked my friend who has religious friends, how do people delude themselves into believing in a god?

He says they aren’t delusional, its called a leap of faith for a reason, you just have to trust.

And that one explanation made me understand religion much better than any religious person actually trying to explain god to me.

Faith is simply faith.

body:
It does make sense too. Historical dating of certain biblical books proves quite clear and quite detailed prophecies of events that occurred even hundreds of years later. 

For example, in The Book of Isaiah, the battle of Babylon was predicted over 100 years before, I think even closer to 200, and the biblical prophecy detailed miniscule details such as: The lakes around the castle being drained, the gates being left unlocked, the battle being won without bloodshed, and the area not being inhabited by mankind ever again. Nowadays it's mostly just visited by people who want to see it. 

Take this for what you will, but it is a little more nuanced than just faith, though faith and trust is certainly a large component of it as well.

https://bible.ucg.org/bible-commentary/Isaiah/Coming-restoration-of-Judah;-Cyrus-foretold;-No-other-God-but-the-Almighty-Creator/ Kind of bland, but just look up Isaiah prophecy babylon cyrus or similar keywords if you're interested to look into it and verify it yourself. All I'm gonna leave here is that the book was written in the 600-700BC era, and the battle that was prophesized happens in 539BC. I thought this might interest you to hear about.

He says they aren’t delusional, its called a leap of faith for a reason, you just have to trust.

And that one explanation made me understand religion much better than any religious person actually trying to explain god to me.

Faith is simply faith.
parent.body_html:
The original tenant of agnosticism was the belief that due to how limited human intelligence is, we have to accept there are answers to questions we will never ever have answered.

Is there a god? Is there a creator? Did everything start off with an explosion of just because? Does the universe have a type of will?

My answer is that its impossible for the human race to ever find out how the universe started, or if someone created it. And we have to accept that.

That’s it.

Anyone that claims they know how the universe started or who created it, is full of shit. End of story.

I asked my friend who has religious friends, how do people delude themselves into believing in a god?

He says they aren’t delusional, its called a leap of faith for a reason, you just have to trust.

And that one explanation made me understand religion much better than any religious person actually trying to explain god to me.

Faith is simply faith.

parent.body:
Forgive me if this comes across as an attack, but it is a tad arrogant to presume we've achieved mastery over the Universe and the rules which it abides by. If we knew all there is to know, then there'd be nothing left for us to uncover, understand and use to our greatest advantage. Every day new advancements in one field or another are made, so we most certainly have not plateaued. Who'd of thought that you could grow a pigment or dye on aluminum foil for example? What I am saying is; the rulebook we abide by, the lens through which we gaze upon this world, changes with each & every discovery made, so we still have a long way to go before we can declare ourselves all knowing and masters of the universe. 

When speaking of Higher Beings like El Elohim, it's only natural to presume He would undoubtedly of a far higher caliber and know the entire rulebook like the back of His hand well in advance. Rules that we have not yet quite grasped ahold of as not every question that torments mankind has been answered. Not even the most brilliant of minds have been able to answer the eternal question of man: is there life after death? One major point of science is to answer our greatest questions or to solve our dilemmas, but there are still many questions we have that after all this time remain unanswered. It seems every day with one discovery, another question must be asked, so to put it simply; we do not know all the rules. Not at all. That much is certainly clear.

Also being faithful there is a quote I cannot seem to find anymore that often resonates with me:

To try and perceive the ways of God is like your toast trying to better understand you. 

It's silly, but it often quells my hubris.

author.bio_html:
Da pacem, Domine, in diebus nostris

Quia non est alius

Qui pugnet pro nobis

Nisi tu Deus noster.

body:
Thank you for being willing to have this discussion! I very much appreciate the understanding you've extended to me as I too can now better see where it is you are coming from, even if we may disagree on certain nuances... I think. Maybe I should have elaborated my position more clearly as I personally do not see the incompatibility between science and faith. They both have their place in my life and often times intermingle in ways that are hard to describe without a great deal of reflection, eloquence and time. 

For example, I thank God for the existence of video games and consider it miraculous how we can make worlds within worlds with pixels and code, but that does not mean I disregard how it is they are able to function and exist in the first place. Even the existence of code often leaves me astounded the longer I think about it. It's merely being thankful that He's allowed such possibilities and wonders in our world. I'd love to see what else is out there, ya know? I do not see how that hurts me or progress, not that I'm saying you are saying as such to anyone here, but there are those that have found my faith revolting when awestruck by these wonders as if I were saying His existence negates the physical plane of existence when I think we should strive to understand both the physical and metaphysical (if the field isn't allowed to be dominated by snake oil salesmen.) The point is though, I believe many educated and modern Christians feel the same way. We attribute the wonders of this world to God and find ourselves in awe of how they work, but it does not mean we disrespect the physical plane and the laws it currently abides by. If anything, many Christians want to see science progress far enough that maybe everyone else will see what we do.

 Of course, I do agree that there are Christians and other religious groups who do stand in the way of progress all because they've convinced themselves that revelations like Evolutionism somehow defeat the core tenets and principles of their faith, rather than simply correcting minor details that are mostly irrelevant in the grand scheme of the Christian framework. Then again, I may be a bit biased towards Creationists for their regular attempts at dismantling our curriculum years back. Similar to the Creationist point, I think harping on the minor detail of one's faith can hold back progress as well, especially if the faithful are also willing to seek out answers alongside atheists and agnostics.

If I may have misunderstood your point on how exactly it gets us nowhere, would you be so kind as to further elaborate on your point for me?

body:
I’ve taken acid and shrooms

I’ve had those thoughts and feelings where I’m just absolutely in awe of the fact that everything exists, and I’ve felt that none of this would be possible unless there was a reason, or even direction (from something).

But my ego stops me from saying, my feelings are absolutely correct, I think the correct answer is admitting, we just don’t know what the hell is going on and we’re just here now, and “now” only exists because we can think about thinking.

Also I understand time doesn’t only mean just a point, I understand it can be a line or diverging lines or parallel lines, or even more concepts we can’t understand.

But even if a concept of some type of will/energy/god/being existed outside of our understanding of space and time, I cannot trust that anyone would know that.

Sorry I’m not trying to argue against you, that’s just what I believe.
body_html:
I’ve taken acid and shrooms

I’ve had those thoughts and feelings where I’m just absolutely in awe of the fact that everything exists, and I’ve felt that none of this would be possible unless there was a reason, or even direction (from something).

But my ego stops me from saying, my feelings are absolutely correct, I think the correct answer is admitting, we just don’t know what the hell is going on and we’re just here now, and “now” only exists because we can think about thinking.

Also I understand time doesn’t only mean just a point, I understand it can be a line or diverging lines or parallel lines, or even more concepts we can’t understand.

But even if a concept of some type of will/energy/god/being existed outside of our understanding of space and time, I cannot trust that anyone would know that.

Sorry I’m not trying to argue against you, that’s just what I believe.
